page.title: 11HUTTON ESTATE - HARDWOODS
page.content: Hardwoods on the Hutton Estate fall into three categories: a){Mature:}Principally oak, but also lime, beech and sycamore. There is a number of specimen trees in the Hall grounds as well as a number of commercial plantations. They are of major landscape significance. Important plantations include Cover Wood and 14 Acre. b){Young:}Often planted among soft- woods and sometimes under planted. Mostly sycamore, often from natural regeneration, but also oak, beech and birch. The Kennel Wood, mainly oak and beech, is the most notable example. c){Poplar:} Lord Inglewood planted many varieties and hybrids. They were established for commercial reasons and now dominate parts of the landscape. Being weak in wind, they are not being replanted as extensively.
